rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today‚Äôs topic is about creating rules and routines with our children.

When rules are part of a routine, they‚Äôre easier to follow. They help children understand what‚Äôs expected, take responsibility, and stay safe ‚Äì all while making the home more calm and peaceful. And that‚Äôs something we all want, right?

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today‚Äôs topic is about creating rules and routines with our children.

When rules are part of a routine, they‚Äôre easier to follow. They help children understand what‚Äôs expected, take responsibility, and stay safe ‚Äì all while making the home more calm and peaceful. And that‚Äôs something we all want, right?

media_title.eng: Tap play to learn how rules and routines can help you and your family

media_transcript.eng:
Greetings, everyone.

Do you have moments in the day with your child that feel stressful? Is it bedtime or getting ready for school?

Rules can help! Having clear rules and routines actually helps children know what is expected of them, which helps reduce the struggles of the more stressful moments in the day.

rows.media_title: Tap play to learn how rules and routines can help you and your family
rows.media_transcript:
Greetings, everyone.

Do you have moments in the day with your child that feel stressful? Is it bedtime or getting ready for school?

Rules can help! Having clear rules and routines actually helps children know what is expected of them, which helps reduce the struggles of the more stressful moments in the day.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Children are more likely to follow rules if you create them together. 

Let‚Äôs look at an example. @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name watches too much TV before finishing her homework. @data.characters.f1_mother.name helps her set a family rule:

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Children are more likely to follow rules if you create them together. 

Let‚Äôs look at an example. @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name watches too much TV before finishing her homework. @data.characters.f1_mother.name helps her set a family rule:

character_1_text.eng: @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name, it is important that you get your homework done so you can do well in school. Let‚Äôs make a rule about watching TV so that you have enough time for homework, too.

rows.character_1_text: @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name, it is important that you get your homework done so you can do well in school. Let‚Äôs make a rule about watching TV so that you have enough time for homework, too.
What do you think would be a fair rule?

character_1_text.eng: What do you think would be a fair rule?

character_2_text.eng: Hmmm‚Ä¶ Maybe I can watch TV as much as I want, but only after I do my homework?

rows.character_2_text: Hmmm‚Ä¶ Maybe I can watch TV as much as I want, but only after I do my homework?

rows.character_1_text: I like that idea, but let‚Äôs limit it to 30 minutes per day so that you have time for other fun and relaxing things too. How does that sound?

character_1_text.eng: I like that idea, but let‚Äôs limit it to 30 minutes per day so that you have time for other fun and relaxing things too. How does that sound?

rows.character_1_text:
Thank you for doing your homework before watching TV, @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name. 
Last night, you mentioned that your math tests have become easier for you. I am proud of you! We can increase your TV time to 45 minutes each day‚Ä¶ as long as you still do your homework first.

character_1_text.eng:
Thank you for doing your homework before watching TV, @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name. 
Last night, you mentioned that your math tests have become easier for you. I am proud of you! We can increase your TV time to 45 minutes each day‚Ä¶ as long as you still do your homework first.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let‚Äôs reflect on how @data.characters.f1_mother.name and @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name created a rule together.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let‚Äôs reflect on how @data.characters.f1_mother.name and @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name created a rule together.

text_2.eng:
Notice how @data.characters.f1_mother.name:

- ü§ùüèæ Involved @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name in creating a realistic rule
- üì∫ Made sure that the rule was consistent (homework has to be done first every day!)
- üëèüèæ Praised and rewarded @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name

quiz_1_question.eng: Why does @data.characters.f1_mother.name ask @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name for her ideas on what the household rule should be?

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: To help her feel involved and heard

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng:
Exactly! When you make rules together with your child, the rules will work better. 

There is more than one right answer! Did you find all of them?

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: To make sure the rule feels fair and works

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng:
Exactly! When you make rules together with your child, the rules will work better. 

There is more than one right answer! Did you find all of them?

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Not quite. Asking for ideas does not mean the parent has no authority. It helps build respect and makes rules more likely to work.

quiz_1_option_4_text.eng: Because she doesn‚Äôt know what to do

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng: Not quite. Asking for ideas is not a sign of weakness ‚Äì it shows care and helps children learn to solve problems together with their parents.

- üëèüèæ Praised and rewarded @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name

rows.quiz_1_option_2_text: She gives her a simple reward

rows.text_2: Exactly! Praise and a simple reward will make it more likely that @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name will keep following the household rules.

text_2.eng: Exactly! Praise and a simple reward will make it more likely that @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name will keep following the household rules.

text_2.eng: Exactly! Praise and a simple reward will make it more likely that @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name will keep following the household rules.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Creating daily routines (like rules around meals, school and bedtime) can help your child feel safe, secure, and calm.

Let‚Äôs look at @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name and her granddaughter, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name. They have set up a routine around bedtime that is working really well!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Creating daily routines (like rules around meals, school and bedtime) can help your child feel safe, secure, and calm.

Let‚Äôs look at @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name and her granddaughter, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name. They have set up a routine around bedtime that is working really well!

character_1_text.eng: I am so happy to see you playing quietly with your building blocks, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name. In 5 minutes, it will be time to get ready for bed. When you are ready for bed, we can read a story together.

rows.character_1_text: I am so happy to see you playing quietly with your building blocks, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name. In 5 minutes, it will be time to get ready for bed. When you are ready for bed, we can read a story together.

character_1_text.eng: Time to get ready for bed, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name. First, let‚Äôs get you nice and clean with a bath.

rows.character_1_text: Time to get ready for bed, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name. First, let‚Äôs get you nice and clean with a bath.
You were so well-behaved in the bath, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name. Now it is time to put your pyjamas on.

character_1_text.eng: You were so well-behaved in the bath, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name. Now it is time to put your pyjamas on.

rows.character_1_text: Well done for putting on your pyjamas by yourself, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name! Now let‚Äôs brush your teeth. Make sure you get the ones in the back of your mouth too!

character_1_text.eng: Well done for putting on your pyjamas by yourself, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name! Now let‚Äôs brush your teeth. Make sure you get the ones in the back of your mouth too!

rows.character_1_text: You did so well getting ready for bed! Now, we have time to read a story. Which book would you like to read?

character_1_text.eng: You did so well getting ready for bed! Now, we have time to read a story. Which book would you like to read?

character_2_text.eng: Yay! Can you read me the story about the lion?

rows.character_2_text: Yay! Can you read me the story about the lion?

rows.character_1_text: ‚ÄúThe end‚Ä¶‚Äù I‚Äôm glad you chose that story for us to read, it‚Äôs one of my favourites! Goodnight, my dear. I love you very much.

character_1_text.eng: ‚ÄúThe end‚Ä¶‚Äù I‚Äôm glad you chose that story for us to read, it‚Äôs one of my favourites! Goodnight, my dear. I love you very much.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let‚Äôs think about what made this routine work well so we can all have peaceful bedtimes in our families.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let‚Äôs think about what made this routine work well so we can all have peaceful bedtimes in our families.

text_2.eng:
@data.characters.f2_grandmother.name did a few things that helped @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name follow the routine: 
- üëèüèæ Praise and connect with @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name before giving instructions
- ü§ùüèæ Promise a simple reward to encourage her
- ‚ö†Ô∏è Give a transition warning for each step of the routine
- 1Ô∏è‚É£ Give one instruction at a time so that @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name is not confused
- üèÜ Praise  @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name after each step

quiz_1_question.eng: How often do you think @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name and @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name follow this routine?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Try again. If @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name and @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name only do these steps once a week, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name would not be able to remember and follow the routine as well as she does here.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Try again. Following these steps only a few times a week can confuse @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name, and she may struggle to follow the routine as well as she does here.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng:
Exactly. Being consistent with a routine ‚Äì especially at the end of the day when everyone is tired ‚Äì makes activities easier to follow for children. 

With a bit of practice, bedtime can become a happy time of connecting with your child!

rows.text_1_facilitator: These four tips will help you create rules and routines to bring more structure and peace in your home.

text_1_facilitator.eng: These four tips will help you create rules and routines to bring more structure and peace in your home.

section_1_text.eng: When you involve your child in making rules they are more likely to follow them.

section_1_extra_text.eng:
Plan rules WITH your child. Discuss the reasons for the rule and ask about their ideas.

Older children can share their own ideas of what they think the rule should be and you can agree together. They will feel appreciated and heard.

section_2_text.eng:
Consider your child‚Äôs age and developmental level when creating rules and routines. They have to be able to do what is expected of them.

Remember: Only introduce one new rule or routine at a time ‚Äì you can add another one later.

section_2_extra_text.eng:
Start with small and clear rules your child can follow. If a rule feels too hard, work together to break it into smaller steps.

Make rules realistic for what your child can do. Be specific ‚Äì instead of ‚Äúclean up,‚Äù say ‚Äúput your blocks away.‚Äù

section_3_text.eng:
Make sure your child follows the rules and routines daily.

That way, your child knows what to expect and this will help them to feel secure. They will learn to be more independent and responsible.

section_3_extra_text.eng: Activities become easier when children learn and get comfortable with the routine.

rows.section_1_text: When you involve your child in making rules they are more likely to follow them.
rows.section_1_extra_text:
Plan rules WITH your child. Discuss the reasons for the rule and ask about their ideas.

Older children can share their own ideas of what they think the rule should be and you can agree together. They will feel appreciated and heard.

Consider your child‚Äôs age and developmental level when creating rules and routines. They have to be able to do what is expected of them.

Remember: Only introduce one new rule or routine at a time ‚Äì you can add another one later.

Start with small and clear rules your child can follow. If a rule feels too hard, work together to break it into smaller steps.

Make rules realistic for what your child can do. Be specific ‚Äì instead of ‚Äúclean up,‚Äù say ‚Äúput your blocks away.‚Äù
rows.section_3_text:
Make sure your child follows the rules and routines daily.

That way, your child knows what to expect and this will help them to feel secure. They will learn to be more independent and responsible.
rows.section_3_extra_text: Activities become easier when children learn and get comfortable with the routine.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Now that you learned a few tips, let‚Äôs come up with ideas for rules and routines in your home.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Now that you learned a few tips, let‚Äôs come up with ideas for rules and routines in your home.

quiz_1_question.eng: Would you like to try one of these rules with your child?

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: Your child can play after finishing homework

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: This is a great rule! Discuss it with your child and family, or come up with a different rule that will help you at home.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: All family members eat dinner together

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: This is a great rule! Discuss it with your child and family, or come up with a different rule that will help you at home.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: Your child helps to clear the dishes after dinner

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: This is a great rule! Discuss it with your child and family, or come up with a different rule that will help you at home.

quiz_1_option_4_text.eng: Your child packs away their toys before bedtime

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng: This is a great rule! Discuss it with your child and family, or come up with a different rule that will help you at home.

quiz_2_question.eng: In which of these areas would you like to create routines with your child?

quiz_2_feedback_1.eng: Wonderful! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child.

quiz_2_feedback_2.eng: Wonderful! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child. Remember bedtime routines work best when they are predictable and calm!

quiz_2_feedback_3.eng: Wonderful! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child. Remember to use positive instructions when setting up this routine.

quiz_2_feedback_4.eng: Wonderful! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child. Remember that mealtime routines work best when they are predictable.

quiz_2_feedback_5.eng: Wonderful! Remember to praise for following through on chore routines! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child.

quiz_2_feedback_6.eng: Wonderful! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Your home activity is to set *one* rule and *one* routine with your child this week. 

Remember to be realistic and consistent, and praise your child for following each rule or routine!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Your home activity is to set *one* rule and *one* routine with your child this week. 

Remember to be realistic and consistent, and praise your child for following each rule or routine!

media_title.eng: Routines helped @data.characters.media_female_7.name and her family. Tap play to hear their story

media_transcript.eng:
Bedtime was always a struggle in our house. My children wanted to keep watching TV and I would always end up shouting at them: ‚ÄúGo to bed now! You know you have to be ready for school early in the morning!‚Äù. Some days I was just too tired, and I would let them watch more TV. 

When we learned in @global.app_name about rules, I learned that it is important to be consistent. I discussed with my children why watching TV till late is a problem, and we came up with a rule together to switch off the TV at 8 and be ready for bed by 8.30. Now everyone knows what is expected of them, and we can end the day peacefully.

quiz_1_question.eng: Can you set one routine and one rule with your child?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: That's great! I hope it makes your home feel easier to manage for everyone.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: You can do it! Setting rules and routines is hard in the beginning, but it becomes easier when you find a way that works for you.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: That's okay. Setting rules is hard and including children can feel uncomfortable, especially if you‚Äôre not used to it. Keep trying until you find a way that works for you and your children. I promise, it will be worth it!

rows.media_title: Routines helped @data.characters.media_female_7.name and her family. Tap play to hear their story
rows.media_transcript:
Bedtime was always a struggle in our house. My children wanted to keep watching TV and I would always end up shouting at them: ‚ÄúGo to bed now! You know you have to be ready for school early in the morning!‚Äù. Some days I was just too tired, and I would let them watch more TV. 

When we learned in @global.app_name about rules, I learned that it is important to be consistent. I discussed with my children why watching TV till late is a problem, and we came up with a rule together to switch off the TV at 8 and be ready for bed by 8.30. Now everyone knows what is expected of them, and we can end the day peacefully.

rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: You can do it! Setting rules and routines is hard in the beginning, but it becomes easier when you find a way that works for you.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: That's okay. Setting rules is hard and including children can feel uncomfortable, especially if you‚Äôre not used to it. Keep trying until you find a way that works for you and your children. I promise, it will be worth it!
